options.label: B

questions.text: A 35-year-old nulliparous woman is diagnosed with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 3. The patient has been sexually active for 19 years and has had 3 lifetime partners. She has been monogamous with her current partner for several months and has a progestin-releasing intrauterine device for contraception. The patient has never used condoms. Menarche occurred at age 9, and menses recur every 28 days and last 3 days. The patient had a plantar wart a few years ago which resolved on its own, but otherwise has no chronic medical conditions. Her mother was diagnosed with endometrial cancer at age 42. Which of the following risk factors contributed the most to the development of this patient's cervical abnormalities?
questions.correct_answer: D. Lack of barrier contraception use
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Lack of barrier contraception use

questions.text: A 22-year-old unvaccinated woman comes to the OPD due to a rash that developed during a recent trip. A week ago, she developed a low-grade fever and arthralgias, followed by numerous pinpoint, pink macules and papules on her face. Over the next 48 hours, the rash spread to her trunk and then her extremities. She went to a local emergency department, where she was diagnosed with a viral illness and also found to be approximately 8 weeks pregnant. Physical examination today reveals postauricular lymphadenopathy. Heart and lung examinations are unremarkable. Fetal heart tones are normal. The fetus is at highest risk for developing which of the following complications?

A 54-year-old postmenopausal woman comes to the OPD due to increasing vaginal pressure for the past 3 months. The patient has had no vaginal bleeding or abnormal discharge. BMl is 18 kg/m. Vital signs are normal. On speculum examination, the anterior vaginal wall bulges with the Valsalva maneuver. On bimanual examination, the uterus is small and mobile. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's presentation?

A 2-week-old infant presents with a history of epistaxis and recurrent rectal bleeding. The parents also reported a history of bleeding from the umbilicus since birth. Laboratory investigations revealed normal prothrombin time, normal thrombin time, normal partial thromboplastin time, normal platelet count and normal function. Urea clot solubility test was positive. What is the most likely deficient factor in this patient?

A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to cough, fever, breathlessness, and chest pain. The patient has a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack- year history. The trachea is central in position. There is dullness to percussion over the lower right lung area compared to the resonance on the left. Auscultation of the right lower lobe reveals breath sounds that are loud, hollow, and high-pitched. When the patient recites the word "ninety-nine" in a normal voice, the sound has higher clarity and intensity over the right base compared to other lung areas. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Accumulation of fluid in pleural space

options.label: B
options.text: Embolic occlusion of a pulmonary segmental artery

options.label: C
options.text: Exudation of neutrophil-rich fluid in the lung parenchyma

options.label: D
options.text: Leakage of air from spontaneous rupture of visceral pleura

questions.correct_answer: C. Exudation of neutrophil-rich fluid in the lung parenchyma
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Exudation of neutrophil-rich fluid in the lung parenchyma

questions.text: Identify the error from the image:

A 34-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to vulvar and perianal itching and vaginal discharge. She has no other concerns. The patient is sexually active with her husband and takes combined estrogen-progestin oral contraceptive pills daily. She has regular monthly menstrual cycles and does not use barrier contraception. The patient took antibiotics 2 weeks ago for a urinary tract infection but has no chronic medical conditions. Pelvic examination shows an erythematous vulva and perineum with excoriations. A thick, white discharge is present that adheres to the vaginal walls. What is the most likely underlying cause?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased glycogen concentration in the vaginal epithelium

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased number of gram-positive bacteria in the vagina

options.label: D
options.text: Increased alkaline discharge by the cervical mucosa

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased number of gram-positive bacteria in the vagina
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Decreased number of gram-positive bacteria in the vagina

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic in her 8th week of pregnancy with complaints of palpitations, weight loss, and heat intolerance. On examination, she has a resting heart rate of 110 bpm, tremors, and mild exophthalmos. Laboratory results show: TSH <0.01 µIU/mL Free T4 Elevated Total T3 Elevated Which of the following is the most appropriate choice for managing her symptoms?

A 29-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of yellowing of the skin and eyes. He denies other symptoms and recalls a similar episode three years ago. Recently, he has noticed dark urine. Laboratory tests reveal a serum bilirubin level of 4.6 mg/dL, predominantly conjugated. Serum AST and ALT levels are within normal limits. A liver biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dubin-Johnson syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive condition characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to impaired hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin. Liver biopsy reveals darkly pigmented granules in hepatocytes, a hallmark of the condition.
  • ➤ Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive condition characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to impaired hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin. Liver biopsy reveals darkly pigmented granules in hepatocytes, a hallmark of the condition.

The patient has a history of menorrhagia, with monthly cycles lasting 7-10 days and brisk blood flow with the passage of large clots. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged fibroid uterus, and she is found to have significant anemia due to blood loss. The patient is prescribed continuous leuprolide therapy. questions.text: In a reproductive-aged woman presenting with foul-smelling discharge, burning sensation, lower abdominal pain, and dysuria, what is the responsible organism based on the findings from the PAP smear shown below?
What is the quintero stage in the following case?

A fetus with intrauterine growth restriction was born prematurely with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and diffuse petechiae at birth. A brain CT was done which is shown below. What is the best method for the diagnosis of the etiological agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Urine examination

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The brain CT shows periventricular calcifications , which are characteristic of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV is a common cause of intrauterine infection leading to IUGR, microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and petechiae at birth. The best method for diagnosing congenital CMV infection is by detecting CMV in the urine within the first 2 to 3 weeks of life. Urinary examination detects CMV viral DNA or pp65 antigen, which is a reliable marker for infection.
  • • periventricular calcifications
  • • cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • • CMV in the urine
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Liver biopsy: Liver biopsy is invasive and not the first-line investigation for diagnosing CMV infection. While it may show histological evidence of infection, it is rarely used due to its risk and limited diagnostic value for confirming congenital CMV.
  • • Option B. Liver biopsy:
  • • Option C. Blood examination: Although blood tests can detect CMV DNA or antibodies, blood examination is not the most sensitive method for the initial diagnosis of congenital CMV infection. It is often used as a secondary test rather than the primary diagnostic tool.
  • • Option C. Blood examination:
  • • Option D. CSF examination: CSF examination may be performed in cases of central nervous system involvement, but it is not the standard test for diagnosing congenital CMV. CSF is more commonly examined in cases of viral encephalitis caused by other viruses.
  • • Option D. CSF examination:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Periventricular calcifications on brain imaging, along with IUGR, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and petechiae, strongly suggest congenital CMV infection . The diagnostic test of choice is a urine examination to detect CMV viral DNA or pp65 antigen.
  • ➤ Periventricular calcifications
  • ➤ congenital CMV infection
  • ➤ urine examination

questions.text: Identify the correct statements: Only one sacral ala is present in Naegele’s pelvis Hand prolapse must be managed by LSCS False labour is rhythmic pain that radiates to thigh and back Constriction ring is due to injudicious use of oxytocin
What is the most appropriate method of screening for carcinoma cervix in low resource setting such as a PHC?

A 12-year-old girl is brought to the OPD for evaluation of short stature. She was an average-sized infant, but, over the past few years, her height-growth velocity has plateaued. The patient has not menstruated. Menarche occurred in her mother at age 14, and both her parents are tall. The patient's height is at <2nd percentile and weight is at the 50th percentile for age and sex. She has no breast buds. She has a low hairline, a short and wide neck, a broad chest, and widely spaced nipples. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's condition?

A 12-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother due to unusual nighttime behavior. The mother reports that once or twice a month over the past year she has found her daughter walking around the house between the hours of midnight and 2 AM. The mother says, "Although her eyes are open, she appears to be in a daze and doesn't respond to me. I guide her back to bed and she goes back to sleep, but I worry that she could get hurt or fall down the stairs if I'm not there." The girl has no recollection of the events. Which of the following EEG patterns is characteristic of the sleep stage associated with this behavior?

A 19-year-old college student who had a history of frequent respiratory infections as a child presents to the OPD. He has been experiencing recurrent episodes of coughing and shortness of breath over the past few months. He also complains of fatigue and chest pain, particularly on the left side. The CT scan reveals a mass in the lower lobe of his left lung as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old P1L1 presents with acute abdominal pain. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease for which she has undergone mitral valve replacement surgery and is on oral Warfarin. On examination, 14 weeks’ abdominal mass was felt. On USG, 8 x 6 cm unilocular cyst with reticular pattern was observed in left ovary. What is the next line of management?
A pregnant female at 30 weeks of gestation presents with calf tenderness. She is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis. What is the next step?

A 7-year-old boy with generalized swelling and frothy urine was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome three months ago but remains unresponsive to corticosteroids. Renal biopsy reveals podocyte foot process effacement and no immune deposits. Which of the following mutations is most likely responsible for his condition?

The patient and her husband have been trying to conceive for the past 6 months and plan intercourse during her fertile window according to an ovulation predictor kit. If fertilization and implantation occurred in this cycle, when would the B-hCG level first be detectable in the serum?

questions.text: A 9-month-old male infant develops progressive renal and hepatic failure. Despite intensive medical therapy, he passes away. Autopsy reveals kidneys with the gross appearance shown in the image below. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Autosomal recessive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) presents in infancy with smooth external kidney surfaces and linear cysts on cut section. It is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene, leading to renal and hepatic failure.
  • ➤ Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) presents in infancy with smooth external kidney surfaces and linear cysts on cut section.
  • ➤ It is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene, leading to renal and hepatic failure.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with polyuria, polydipsia, progressive vision loss, and a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Further evaluation reveals optic atrophy, poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, and diabetes insipidus. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of DIDMOAD syndrome. Which of the following genes is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) WFS1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ WFS1 gene mutations are responsible for DIDMOAD syndrome (Wolfram Syndrome) , which presents with a combination of diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, optic atrophy, and deafness.
  • ➤ WFS1 gene mutations are responsible for DIDMOAD syndrome (Wolfram Syndrome) , which presents with a combination of diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, optic atrophy, and deafness.
  • ➤ WFS1
  • ➤ DIDMOAD syndrome (Wolfram Syndrome)

questions.text: All of the following are included in high-risk pregnancy under Govt of India except:

A 56-year-old postmenopausal woman arrives at the gynecology clinic reporting a persistent, foul-smelling vaginal discharge that has been present for several weeks. She also notices blood-tinged mucus intermittently. CECT is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

A 20-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to 6 hours of right lower quadrant pain. The pain came on suddenly and has become intense and constant. The patient has had 2 sexual partners in the last year and has a history of chlamydial cervicitis. She takes ibuprofen for dysmenorrhea on the first day of her menses. The patient has a 6-cm, right ovarian cyst, which was noted on ultrasound last year. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Temperature is 37.2° C (99° F), blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 104/min. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to deep palpation in the right lower quadrant. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Leukocyte count is 8,000/mm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
All of the following are contraindications of breastfeeding except:

A 10-minute-old boy is being evaluated in the delivery room. The patient was born at term to a 30-year-old primigravida woman. Pregnancy was unremarkable, but labor was complicated by recurrent late decelerations necessitating vacuum assistance for vaginal delivery. Apgar scores were 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), pulse is 170/min, and respirations are 40/min. Scalp examination shows large, fluctuant swelling at the occiput that extends bilaterally to the ears, superiorly toward the crown, and inferiorly into the nape of the neck. This patient's hemorrhage is most likely located between which of the following structures?
When is delayed cord clamping done?

options.label: A
options.text: Term and preterm babies irrespective of birth weights

options.label: B
options.text: Vigorous term and preterm babies requiring resuscitation

options.label: D
options.text: Only term babies born at 37 weeks

questions.correct_answer: A. Term and preterm babies irrespective of birth weights
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Term and preterm babies irrespective of birth weights

A 6-year-old child presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. CPAM

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The images provided, including ultrasound, CT scan, and X-ray findings, are consistent with Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) .
  • • Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM)
  • • Key features of CPAM :
  • • CPAM
  • • Ultrasound: Shows multiple cystic spaces within the lung parenchyma. CT scan: Confirms the presence of air-filled cystic lesions in the lung fields. X-ray: May show cystic areas or hyperinflation, depending on the size and type of lesions.
  • • Ultrasound: Shows multiple cystic spaces within the lung parenchyma.
  • • Ultrasound:
  • • CT scan: Confirms the presence of air-filled cystic lesions in the lung fields.
  • • CT scan:
  • • X-ray: May show cystic areas or hyperinflation, depending on the size and type of lesions.
  • • X-ray:
  • • CPAM is a congenital condition characterized by abnormal development of the lung tissue, leading to the formation of cystic or adenomatoid lesions. It often presents in childhood with recurrent respiratory infections due to impaired drainage and ventilation.
  • • recurrent respiratory infections
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pyopneumothorax: This would present with an air-fluid level and features of infection (fever, acute symptoms), which are not the primary findings here.
  • • Option A. Pyopneumothorax:
  • • air-fluid level
  • • Option C. CDH (Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia): CDH presents with abdominal contents herniating into the thoracic cavity, causing mediastinal shift and respiratory distress, which is not seen in this case.
  • • Option C. CDH (Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia):
  • • mediastinal shift
  • • Option D. Lung abscess: Lung abscess typically presents as a thick-walled cavity with air-fluid levels , which is not the pattern seen here.
  • • Option D. Lung abscess:
  • • thick-walled cavity with air-fluid levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) presents with recurrent respiratory infections due to abnormal lung development and cystic changes. Imaging studies, including ultrasound and CT, confirm the diagnosis by identifying multiple cystic lesions within the lung.
  • ➤ recurrent respiratory infections

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after accidental ingestion of a chicken bone that lodged in his esophagus. Upper endoscopy is performed and the bone is successfully removed. However, the patient is incidentally found to have mild hypercalcemia on laboratory testing. Further questioning reveals that several of his family members also have mild hypercalcemia. Subsequent laboratory studies show a borderline high parathyroid hormone concentration, very low urinary calcium level, and normal 25-hydroxyvitamin D level. A mutation in which of the following receptors is most likely responsible for this patient's laboratory abnormalities?

options.label: A
options.text: Intracellular receptor with a DNA-binding domain

options.label: B
options.text: Membrane-bound receptor coupled with a G protein

options.label: D
options.text: Transmembrane receptor causing activation of Janus kinase/STAT pathway

questions.correct_answer: B. Membrane-bound receptor coupled with a G protein
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Membrane-bound receptor coupled with a G protein

questions.text: A 3-week-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to lethargy. The patient was breastfeeding well until this morning when she became increasingly difficult to rouse. She was born at term to a 35-year-old woman who had a spontaneous vaginal delivery at home. The patient did not receive any vaccinations or medications after birth due to parental preference. Head circumference is at the 99th percentile. Weight and length are at the 25th percentile. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Physical examination shows a large, bulging anterior fontanelle. The eyes are driven downward, and the patient does not appear to be able to look upward. No scalp swelling is present. lntracranial hemorrhage is confirmed on CT scan of the head. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the OPD to discuss abnormal laboratory results. The patient is at 18 weeks gestation based on her last menstrual period. She has no chronic medical conditions and takes no daily medications. Results of the quadruple screen performed previously are as follows: Maternal serum a- fetoprotein: High Unconjugated estriol : Low B-hCG: Low lnhibin A: Low Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother. She is concerned because although tall, her son looks much younger than his peers and shows no signs of "masculinity." On physical examination, the boy has poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics. He is unable to distinguish smells but has good visual acuity. Which of the following pathways is most likely defective in this patient?

The patient has had increasing shortness of breath while climbing stairs and during long walks for the past few weeks but has had no cough, sick contacts, hemoptysis, orthopnea, or chest pain. Blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 18/min. Fetal heart tones are normal. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. options.text: Administration of oxytocin after shoulder delivery

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with spotting per vaginum and cervical erosion. Which of the following are the most appropriate investigations for her?

An 18-year-old primigravida at 27 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department due to severe right upper quadrant pain. The pain started 2 hours ago, and the patient has also had nausea, vomiting, and irregular uterine contractions. Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) is 220 U/L and alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) is 240 U/L. CECT is shown below. This patient is most likely at risk for which of the following complications?

A 32-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department due to irregular contractions for the past 3 hours. They are not painful and occur every 7-15 minutes. She has had no vaginal bleeding or leakage of fluid. Fetal movement is normal. The patient's pregnancy has been uncomplicated. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and has no palpable contractions. Fundal height is at 36 cm. The cervix is closed on digital cervical examination. Blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min. BMI is 28 kg/m2. Nonstress test monitoring is shown in the exhibit. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

A 25-year-old primigravida at 37 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department with constant, excruciating abdominal pain and sudden vaginal bleeding for the past 3 hours. The patient is Rh negative and received Rh(D) immunoglobulin at 28 weeks gestation. Blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and pulse is 118/min. Physical examination shows a firm and tender uterus. Speculum examination reveals a moderate amount of bleeding coming from an open cervical os. Fetal heart tracing shows a baseline of 105/min and no variability. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's bleeding?

options.label: A
options.text: Attachment of the placenta onto the myometrium

options.label: B
options.text: Injury to the fetal placental vessels

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary stimulus for the closure of the ductus arteriosus?

options.label: D
options.text: Low levels of CO2 in blood

questions.text: A woman presents with chronic lower abdominal pain. Ultrasound reveals a right adnexal mass as shown below. MRI shows a 4x5 cm T1 hyperintense lesion with fat suppression, while the T2 sequence demonstrates low signal intensity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not true about breast milk jaundice?

options.label: A
options.text: Seen in 3-4% of exclusively breastfed children

options.label: C
options.text: Exclusive breastfeeding with total bilirubin more than 10 mg/dl after 3-4 weeks of birth

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman at 14 weeks gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. With the exception of some mild fatigue. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated to date. On physical examination, the patient's abdomen appears larger than would be expected at 14 weeks. An obstetrical ultrasound reveals twins, a male and a female. Which of the following describes the most likely type of twin placentation in this patient?
Which of the following does not constitute a germ cell tumor?

A newborn is being evaluated in the nursery. The patient was born at term via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 23-year-old woman. The mother developed dark terminal facial hair and a deepened voice during the pregnancy. Examination shows ambiguous genitalia and clitoromegaly. Laboratory studies reveal elevated serum levels of testosterone and androstenedione. Karyotype testing shows a 46,XX genotype. Ultrasound of the newborn shows a normal-sized uterus. This infant's presentation is most likely due to deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
A 35-year-old woman accompanied by her mother-in-law comes to the infertility clinic. She has been having regular intercourse for 6 months but is not able to conceive. What is the next best step?

options.label: B
options.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.text: Identify the correct statements about most common associations in pelvis types: Persistent OP-Anthropoid Face to pubis-Android ROP-Platypelloid LOT-Gynecoid
All of the following markers are increased in PIH except:
A 48-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with vaginal bleeding. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 6 mm. What is the next best step in management?
Which of the following is included in neonatal sepsis screen:

A 26-year-old woman, para 0, comes to the OPD for follow-up of irregular menstrual periods. Endometrial sampling reveals coiled glands filled with carbohydrate-rich mucus, edematous stroma, and tortuous spiral arteries. At which time point on the graph below was the endometrial sampling most likely obtained?

A female with abdominal pain and bleeding per vagina with 3 months of amenorrhea. On examination her BP was 90/60mmHg. Which of the following statements is/are true about ectopic pregnancy? Abdominal pain is the most common presenting symptom of ectopic pregnancy and may be present in at least 90% of the patients. PID and sexually transmitted infections are a major risk factor. Low values of progesterone are usually diagnostic of ectopic pregnancy, however there's no specific value to completely rule out or exclude ectopic pregnancy. Oral methotrexate is a viable medical alternative to surgery in ectopic pregnancy patients presenting with shock or renal failure.
If a bilateral tubal block is seen on hysterosalpingogram - which of the following is the next step?

A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to difficulty breathing that started 6 hours earlier. The patient has had rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, and a dry cough for the past day. Pulse oximetry is 99% on room air. The patient has biphasic stridor when crying. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

A 65-year-old man comes to the OPD due to advanced prostate cancer with bone metastases. For the last 4 months, he has been treated with a GnRH agonist, which has significantly reduced his bone pain. However, the patient now reports discomfort at the anterior chest wall. Physical examination reveals bilateral, mildly tender enlargement of the breast tissue behind the nipple-areolar complex. Early initiation of which of the following medications would be most appropriate for preventing this patient's breast symptoms?

A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 16 weeks gestation undergoes routine prenatal screening. Her serum markers are analyzed to assess the risk of fetal chromosomal abnormalities. Among the markers evaluated, which one is not included in the standard quadruple screening panel?

An athlete with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 presents with secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. Her laboratory investigations reveal FSH 2; LH 0.3; TSH 1.2; Prolactin 20 ng/ml. What is the underlying cause of this condition?
A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image?
A 2-day-old newborn presents with respiratory distress and abdominal distension. A nasogastric tube was inserted, and an X-ray was performed as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A neonate has bilateral chorioretinitis and presents with subtle seizures. Head CT is shown below. What is the causative organism?

A 32-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a positive pregnancy test, but transvaginal ultrasound does not show an intrauterine pregnancy. Endometrial biopsy reveals hypersecretory glands with nuclear atypia and poor decidualization. This histological finding is consistent with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arias-Stella reaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Arias-Stella reaction is a histological hallmark of ectopic pregnancy. It is characterized by hypersecretory glands with nuclear atypia and is caused by inadequate hormonal support, particularly low progesterone, leading to poor decidualization. This finding is a key diagnostic feature in patients with suspected ectopic pregnancy.
  • ➤ The Arias-Stella reaction is a histological hallmark of ectopic pregnancy.
  • ➤ Arias-Stella reaction
  • ➤ It is characterized by hypersecretory glands with nuclear atypia and is caused by inadequate hormonal support, particularly low progesterone, leading to poor decidualization.
  • ➤ This finding is a key diagnostic feature in patients with suspected ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: Phototherapy is a commonly used treatment for neonatal jaundice to reduce elevated serum bilirubin levels. Which mechanism of action in phototherapy primarily contributes to the reduction in serum bilirubin levels?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The primary mechanism of phototherapy in reducing bilirubin is structural isomerization , which transforms unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble isomers that can be excreted directly by the kidneys.
  • ➤ The primary mechanism of phototherapy in reducing bilirubin is structural isomerization , which transforms unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble isomers that can be excreted directly by the kidneys.
  • ➤ structural isomerization

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of developmental delay and recurrent tonic-clonic seizures with hyperactivity. He is at the 17th percentile for head circumference. Examination shows protrusion of the mandible, strabismus, and a laughing facial expression. His gait is unsteady. He has a vocabulary of about 200 words and cannot speak in full sentences. Karyotype analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype without chromosomal deletions. Which of the following genetic mechanisms best explains this patient’s findings?

options.label: D
options.text: De novo mutation of MECP2 on the X chromosome

questions.text: Identify the correct statements: Social smile - 2 months Hand regard - 2 years Babbling gibberish - 15 months Walk upstairs with alternate foot - 4 years Copy a circle - 2 years

A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth had pink extremities, a heart rate of 99/min, strong crying, active movement, and responded to stimulation by crying. The APGAR score for this newborn is ________.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 9

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ APGAR scoring evaluates five objective signs at 1 and 5 minutes after birth: color, heart rate, respiration, muscle tone, and reflex irritability. A perfect score of 10 indicates a healthy and well-adapted newborn.
  • ➤ APGAR scoring evaluates five objective signs at 1 and 5 minutes after birth: color, heart rate, respiration, muscle tone, and reflex irritability. A perfect score of 10 indicates a healthy and well-adapted newborn.

questions.text: A 22y primigravida is overdue by 2 weeks. She visits the OPD with complaints of vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain on the right side. On Examination, her vitals are stable. Abdomen examination is unremarkable. A bimanual examination reveals a bulky, soft uterus with no tenderness and no adnexal mass. Beta hCG is 1400 IU. An ultrasound reveals a trilaminar endometrium, and both the adnexa are normal. The next best step is:
questions.correct_answer: A. Repeat serum beta HCG after 48h
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Repeat serum beta HCG after 48h

questions.text: A full-term baby was born 14 hours ago. As the pediatrician on duty, you are called to assess the newborn for a routine check-up. On examination, the baby appears well, with no apparent abnormalities. The mother, however, expresses concern as the baby has not yet passed any stool or urine. She asks for clarification on what is considered the normal time frame for a newborn to pass urine and meconium. What would be the appropriate response?

options.label: A
options.text: Urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours

options.label: B
options.text: Urine within 12 hours and meconium within 24 hours

options.label: C
options.text: Urine within 24 hours and meconium within 12 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Urine within 48 hours and meconium within 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: A. Urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ A healthy, full-term newborn is expected to pass urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours after birth. Delays beyond these time frames may indicate underlying pathologies and require medical evaluation.
  • ➤ A healthy, full-term newborn is expected to pass urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours after birth.
  • ➤ Delays beyond these time frames may indicate underlying pathologies and require medical evaluation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with?
All are true regarding peripartum cardiomyopathy except?

options.label: A
options.text: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage 2B was advised radiotherapy. Which of the following statements regarding radiotherapy is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Point B is 3 cm lateral to point A

options.label: B
options.text: Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal

options.label: C
options.text: Point A receives a dose of 8000 cGy

options.label: D
options.text: Point B receives a dose of 6000 cGy

questions.correct_answer: B. Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, the second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and the third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 7-week-old boy is evaluated for persistent hypoxia. He has been in the neonatal intensive care unit since birth. He was born at 29 weeks gestation due to placental abruption and weighed 1150g. Six hours after delivery, the patient developed tachypnoea, grunting, and cyanosis, a chest x-ray revealed ground-glass opacities. Surfactant was administered and mechanical ventilation was initiated. He remained on mechanical ventilation for the first 3 weeks of life. Ever since ventilation was discontinued, the patient has remained hypoxic and continues to require oxygen administration by nasal cannula. Chest radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's current presentation?

A 6-year-old girl is evaluated for early-onset puberty and multiple bone lesions. On examination, she has café-au-lait spots as shown below. Hormonal tests confirm hyperfunction of multiple endocrine glands. What is the underlying genetic mutation in this condition?

22-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the OPD for worsening acne on her face and body over the last 6 months. She initially attributed the acne to her diet and has been eating healthier to improve the acne and lose weight. The patient has lost 6.8 kg in the last 3 months, but the acne has not improved. BMI is 42 kg/m2. Coarse hair is noted on the chin and upper lip. Pelvic examination shows an enlarged clitoris but otherwise normal external genitalia. Laboratory results reveal elevated total testosterone and normal dehydroepiandrosterone sulphate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? Normal stature Thelarche – absent FSH, LH – high Karyotype - 46 XX
A 2-year-old child presents with swelling of the feet, apathy, and a protuberant abdomen. Examination is shown. Which of the following findings is least likely to be present in this child?

A 3-month-old girl is developing cataracts. Other than not having a social smile or being able to track objects visually, all other aspects of the girl’s examination are normal. Tests on the baby’s urine are positive for reducing sugar but negative for glucose. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this girl?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Galactokinase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The 3-month-old girl presents with cataracts and a positive test for reducing sugars in the urine, but negative for glucose. These findings suggest a metabolic disorder involving galactose. The deficiency of galactokinase, an enzyme responsible for the phosphorylation of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate, leads to the accumulation of galactose in the blood (galactosemia) and urine (galactosuria).
  • • In the lens of the eye, accumulated galactose is converted to galactitol, a sugar alcohol, by the enzyme aldose reductase. Galactitol causes osmotic changes in the lens, leading to water retention and cataract formation. The absence of other systemic findings such as liver damage or neurologic effects, which are associated with other disorders of galactose metabolism, points to an isolated galactokinase deficiency.
  • • Thus, the girl's clinical and biochemical presentation is most consistent with galactokinase deficiency.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Aldolase B: Aldolase B is involved in the metabolism of fructose. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to hereditary fructose intolerance, a severe disorder characterized by hypoglycemia, vomiting, failure to thrive, and liver and kidney damage upon fructose ingestion. Cataracts are not typically seen in this condition. Since the presentation in this case is related to galactose metabolism rather than fructose metabolism, aldolase B deficiency is not the correct answer.
  • • Option A. Aldolase B:
  • • Option B. Fructokinase: Fructokinase deficiency causes essential fructosuria, a benign condition in which fructose is excreted in the urine due to the inability to phosphorylate fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. This condition does not cause systemic effects, cataracts, or urine findings as described in this case. Thus, fructokinase deficiency is not relevant to the girl's clinical presentation.
  • • Option B. Fructokinase:
  • • Option D. Galactose 1-phosphate uridylyl transferase (GALT): Deficiency of GALT results in classic galactosemia, a severe condition characterized by cataracts, hepatomegaly, liver dysfunction, and neurologic effects such as developmental delay and seizures. The absence of systemic effects such as liver damage or neurologic symptoms in this child makes GALT deficiency less likely. Additionally, classic galactosemia typically presents earlier in infancy with more severe systemic involvement.
  • • Option D. Galactose 1-phosphate uridylyl transferase (GALT):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Galactokinase deficiency leads to galactose accumulation, which is converted to galactitol in the lens by aldose reductase, causing cataracts.

questions.text: Identify the correct statements: The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor are Engagement → Crowning → External rotation → Restitution cOCPS have no role in protection against HIV and STDs Warning bleeds are a feature of placenta previa An upper segment cesarean section is done in case of perimortem cesarean section if there is no return of spontaneous circulation in 5 minutes in a pregnant woman who has experienced total cardiopulmonary arrest

A 35-year-old woman with symptomatic uterine fibroids is scheduled for surgery. During the procedure, the surgeon uses the instrument shown in the image. What procedure is this instrument most commonly used for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Open myomectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bonney’s myomectomy clamp is commonly used during an open myomectomy to control bleeding while removing uterine fibroids.
  • ➤ The Bonney’s myomectomy clamp is commonly used during an open myomectomy to control bleeding while removing uterine fibroids.
  • ➤ Bonney’s myomectomy clamp
  • ➤ open myomectomy

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of this placental pathology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Placenta succenturiata

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Placenta succenturiata involves the presence of accessory lobes, which may lead to postpartum hemorrhage if retained after delivery. Prompt ultrasound evaluation is critical to confirm retained tissue in such cases.
  • ➤ Placenta succenturiata involves the presence of accessory lobes, which may lead to postpartum hemorrhage if retained after delivery.
  • ➤ Placenta succenturiata
  • ➤ postpartum hemorrhage
  • ➤ Prompt ultrasound evaluation is critical to confirm retained tissue in such cases.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman, in her 28th week of gestation, presents to the emergency room with acute severe abdominal pain that started suddenly. She feels febrile. She denies vaginal bleeding, or regular uterine contractions. On examination, her abdomen is tense and tender. Laboratory investigations reveal a WBC count of 15000 cells/µl. There is no evidence of cervical dilatation or effacement. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester visits the clinic for a routine checkup. She asks about the physiological changes occurring in her urinary system during pregnancy. Which of the following changes does not occur in the urinary system during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increased activity of ureters

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pregnancy, progesterone relaxes smooth muscles , leading to reduced ureteral activity , which can result in hydroureter and hydronephrosis. Other urinary changes include increased GFR , RBF , and bladder muscle hypertrophy.
  • ➤ In pregnancy, progesterone relaxes smooth muscles , leading to reduced ureteral activity , which can result in hydroureter and hydronephrosis.
  • ➤ progesterone relaxes smooth muscles
  • ➤ reduced ureteral activity
  • ➤ Other urinary changes include increased GFR , RBF , and bladder muscle hypertrophy.
  • ➤ GFR
  • ➤ RBF

questions.text: A 34-year-old female Jennifer is pregnant with twins. She has a history of one live birth delivered at the beginning of 8th month and two abortions. What is her obstetric score?

A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with a 4-cm squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva that involves the urethral meatus. Her medical history includes systemic lupus erythematosus. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection

questions.correct_answer: D. Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For locally advanced vulvar cancer involving the urethral meatus, the standard treatment is radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection to achieve local control and prevent metastasis.
  • ➤ For locally advanced vulvar cancer involving the urethral meatus, the standard treatment is radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection to achieve local control and prevent metastasis.
  • ➤ locally advanced vulvar cancer
  • ➤ radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about non-invasive prenatal testing?

options.label: A
options.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum.

options.label: B
options.text: It is used for the confirmation of trisomy 13, 18 and 21.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is used for the confirmation of trisomy 13, 18 and 21.

questions.text: A pathologist reviewing a case of suspected ectopic pregnancy finds histological evidence of ovarian tissue in the sac wall, intact fallopian tubes, and attachment to the uterus by the ovarian ligament. Which criteria are used to diagnose this type of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Spiegelberg criteria are used to diagnose ovarian ectopic pregnancy and include confirmation of a gestational sac in the ovary, intact fallopian tubes, ovarian tissue in the sac wall, and attachment to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.
  • ➤ The Spiegelberg criteria are used to diagnose ovarian ectopic pregnancy and include confirmation of a gestational sac in the ovary, intact fallopian tubes, ovarian tissue in the sac wall, and attachment to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.
  • ➤ Spiegelberg criteria

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation is found to have an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 5 cm and absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical artery on Doppler ultrasound. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform daily Doppler assessments and wait for improvement

options.label: B
options.text: Administer corticosteroids and delay delivery until 36 weeks

questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF) on umbilical artery Doppler indicates severe placental insufficiency . Immediate delivery is necessary to prevent fetal hypoxia and intrauterine fetal death, especially after 34 weeks of gestation.
  • ➤ Absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF) on umbilical artery Doppler indicates severe placental insufficiency .
  • ➤ Absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF)
  • ➤ placental insufficiency
  • ➤ Immediate delivery is necessary to prevent fetal hypoxia and intrauterine fetal death, especially after 34 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old nulliparous woman in active labor has been pushing for the past two hours without progress and feels extremely fatigued. The CTG remains normal. On examination, the fetal head is 1 cm above the ischial spines and in the occipitoanterior position. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Emergency cesarean section

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For prolonged second-stage labor with no descent of the fetal head and maternal exhaustion, emergency cesarean section is indicated, especially when the fetal station remains high, as operative vaginal delivery in such cases carries significant risks.
  • ➤ For prolonged second-stage labor with no descent of the fetal head and maternal exhaustion, emergency cesarean section is indicated, especially when the fetal station remains high, as operative vaginal delivery in such cases carries significant risks.
  • ➤ emergency cesarean section

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Asperger syndrome in a child?

options.label: C
options.text: Subnormal intelligence is a consistent feature

questions.text: A 17-year-old adolescent presents to the gynecology clinic with a history of severe menstrual pain and recurrent pelvic infections since the onset of menstruation. She reports cyclical pain coinciding with her menstrual periods and has experienced occasional urinary tract infections. On physical examination, there is a palpable pelvic mass. Ultrasound imaging reveals a duplicated uterine cavity with one side showing an hematometra and absence of the left kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 3-minute-old newborn is being resuscitated due to signs of respiratory distress. Where should the clinical team place the pulse oximeter to measure oxygen saturation in this infant?

A 32-year-old woman is diagnosed with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Imaging studies reveal that the neoplasm has metastasized to her lungs. According to the FIGO staging system for GTN, which stage corresponds to this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, lung metastases classify the disease as Stage III according to FIGO staging. Proper staging is critical for guiding management and determining prognosis.
  • ➤ In gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, lung metastases classify the disease as Stage III according to FIGO staging.
  • ➤ lung metastases
  • ➤ Stage III
  • ➤ Proper staging is critical for guiding management and determining prognosis.

questions.text: A complex febrile seizure is defined by all of the following except:

options.label: C

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, G5P4L4, presents at 10 weeks of gestation with a third-degree uterine prolapse. She reports discomfort and the sensation of a bulge in her vagina, which has worsened since her last pregnancy. Considering her current pregnancy and the degree of prolapse, what would be the most appropriate management option for her condition at this time?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ring pessary is the most appropriate and effective non-surgical management option for third-degree uterine prolapse in pregnant women, providing necessary support and alleviating symptoms while minimizing risks during pregnancy.
  • ➤ Ring pessary is the most appropriate and effective non-surgical management option for third-degree uterine prolapse in pregnant women, providing necessary support and alleviating symptoms while minimizing risks during pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the likely genetic mutation in the following condition?
While attending to a woman in active labor, a midwife identifies a prolapsed umbilical cord during a vaginal examination. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Gently attempt to reposition the cord back into the vaginal canal

options.label: C
options.text: Place the patient in the Trendelenburg

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a vaginal examination to confirm the fetal presentation

questions.correct_answer: C. Place the patient in the Trendelenburg

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman in active labor presents at term. Clinical pelvimetry reveals an oval-shaped pelvic inlet, where the anteroposterior diameter is greater than the transverse diameter. On abdominal examination, sub-umbilical flattening is noted, and the fetal heart is auscultated on the flanks. What is the most likely type of pelvis?

A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of infertility and light menstrual periods for the past year. She has a history of multiple miscarriages that required dilation and curettage (D&C). Which is the best step in her management?

A 6-year-old girl is brought to the outpatient clinic for a checkup. She reached all developmental milestones until the age of 24 months. Since then, she has become more distant and less socially engaging. Verbal language consists mostly of grunting and loud nonverbal yelling, a severe decline from her toddler years when she could speak in three- to four-word sentences. She has never been completely toilet trained and has difficulty following verbal commands from her caregivers. What is the most likely disorder in this child?

A neonate is delivered with meconium-stained amniotic fluid. Shortly after birth, the baby has bloody vomitus, and the medical team wants to determine whether the blood is fetal or maternal in origin. Which of the following is the qualitative test used to differentiate fetal blood from maternal blood in such situations?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Apt-Downey test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Apt-Downey test (alkali denaturation test) is a qualitative test that differentiates fetal hemoglobin (HbF) from maternal hemoglobin (HbA) based on resistance to alkali denaturation. It is used in clinical settings to identify whether blood in neonatal vomitus, stool, or amniotic fluid is fetal or maternal in origin.
  • ➤ The Apt-Downey test (alkali denaturation test) is a qualitative test that differentiates fetal hemoglobin (HbF) from maternal hemoglobin (HbA) based on resistance to alkali denaturation.
  • ➤ Apt-Downey test
  • ➤ It is used in clinical settings to identify whether blood in neonatal vomitus, stool, or amniotic fluid is fetal or maternal in origin.

questions.text: A child presents with erythematous lesions as shown below. What is the likely genetic defect?

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No haemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treatment with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 49-year-old woman, gravida 5 para 5, comes to the OPD due to involuntary, intermittent loss of urine over the past 5 months. The patient loses a small amount of urine when asked to cough. She has no dysuria, urgency, or hematuria and usually awakens once a night to void. Postvoid residual urine volume is 40 mL. Clean-catch unnalysis results are as follows: Blood-negative. Glucose-negative Leukocyte esterase- negative Nitrites- Negative White blood cells- 3-5/hpf Bacteria - none Serum hemoglobin A1c is 7.7%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

A 62-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the OPD for follow-up after right adnexal enlargement was found on routine pelvic examination 2 weeks ago. Pelvic ultrasound reveals a 5-cm right ovarian cyst. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial course of action for this patient?

A 40-year-old nulligravida woman comes to the office with a 2-month history of worsening right pelvic pain. She experiences the pain daily, and its intensity does not vary during her menstrual cycle. In addition, the patient's waist size has increased despite a decreased appetite. Pelvic examination shows an irregularly shaped, fixed adnexal mass. One week later, she undergoes surgery to remove a large ovarian neoplasm. Within the true pelvis, the surgeon can most likely palpate the right ureter immediately anterior to which of the following structures?

A 32-year-old lady underwent copper-T IUCD insertion 2 months post-partum. She has now presented with pain abdomen. The thread of the IUCD is not visible. Her pelvic radiograph is shown below. What is the appropriate step in the management of this patient?

A 50-year-old woman is diagnosed to have endometrial carcinoma on biopsy. She wishes to understand the high-risk factors for development of endometrial cancer. Which of the following is not a risk factor for development of endometrial carcinoma?
A 3-month-old infant presents for vaccination, and the physician discusses options for rotavirus vaccines. Which of the following is a true statement regarding Rotarix and Rotavac vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: Rotavac is a pentavalent vaccine targeting multiple serotypes of rotavirus.

options.label: B
options.text: Rotarix is a live attenuated monovalent vaccine targeting serotype G1P[8].

options.label: C
options.text: Both vaccines are subunit vaccines and administered intramuscularly.

options.label: D
options.text: Rotarix requires a three-dose schedule as per the National Immunization Schedule.

questions.correct_answer: B. Rotarix is a live attenuated monovalent vaccine targeting serotype G1P[8].

questions.text: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is maximum when the mother is infected between:

On doing a per-vaginal examination of a woman in labor, you were able to palpate the mouth with hard alveolar margins, nose, malar eminence, and supraorbital ridges of the fetus. Which of the following would have been the engaging diameter for this presentation?
